Information pertaining to a specific instance of drug characteristic (color, shape, markings etc).
Provides the 'value' part of the name-value pair describing the drug product appearance characteristic.
The attribute is marked as "mandatory" as there must be a value for a mandatory code.
Information about how the dispensed drug is or should be contained
May influence prescribing quantities, and also allows conveying instructions with respect to special packaging such as compliance packaging.
The quantity of the medication dosage form contained in the package given or to be given to the patient.
Because of the constraint imposed by the RIM that in a role, PQ.DRUG must be expressed as a ratio, the numerator should be the package quantity and the denominator a '1'.
Sometimes ordering and dispensing is by package rather than individual units, and package is important in calculating total amount supplied.
Identification of which ingredients are contained (or are not contained) in a drug, along with their respective quantities.

Useful to providers in deciding appropriate use instruction (dosage specification) for patients. Also important in checking for potential adverse reactions to non-active ingredients. For compounds, allows contraindication checking against ingredients of custom compounds.
An indication that a drug does not contain the specified ingredient (active or inactive).
Useful for filtering searches. Allows providers to search for drugs not containing a specific active ingredients or excipients. E.g. lactose-free, gluten-free, etc.
Because product descriptions (particularly herbals) occasionally use the phrase "may contain", this attribute allows null values.
The quantity of the ingredient in a drug. This is represented/measured in various forms/units including: mg, mg/vol, %, etc.
Essential for evaluating appropriate dosage based on strength, as well as for creating custom compounds with proper composition.
Associates a drug product with the organization responsible for producing it.
May be important for tracing adverse events and for performing drug searches.
Identity of the organization that manufactured the drug product.
Useful in distinguishing and grouping drug products
An identifier denoting a specific drug manufacturer.
Allows sending of identifiers in place of manufacturer name. May be used in drug search where specific manufacturer is a criterion.
The name of the drug manufacturer.
Used in reporting.
The attribute is marked as "mandatory" because there will always be a name for an organization.
Represents a particular medicine or herbal product which might be prescribed or administered.
Allows retrieval of summary about one or more products when searching for a medication

An identifier for a type of drug. Depending on where the drug is being referenced, the drug may be identified at different levels of abstraction. E.g. Manufactured drug (including vaccines), generic formulation, generic, therapeutic class, etc.

Used to ensure clear communication by uniquely identifying a particular drug product when prescribing or dispensing. This attribute is only constrained to 'required' because some custom compounds will not have unique identifiers.
The name assigned to a drug.

Names are used for human reference communication, to allow selection from dropdowns and for local searching. Up to two names are supported: a 'search name' which is fully formed with no abbreviations, and a 'display name' which may contain abbreviations to fit within a smaller area on the screen. Because names are the one attribute that exist for all attributes, this element is mandatory.
A free form textual description of a drug. This usually is only recorded for custom compounds, providing instructions on the composition and creation of the compound.
Allows description of compound ingredients and/or recipe in free text form.
Indicates the form in which the drug product must be, or has been manufactured or custom prepared.
Provides a constrained vocabulary for describing dose forms. The form of the drug influences how it can be used by the patient.
A categorization system that shows where a drug fits into a hierarchy of drug classification. Examples include: therapeutic class, generic drug, generic formulation, and manufactured drug.
Allows filtering and drill-down of drug products, as well as decision making with respect to substitutability, etc.
At least one of drug code or drug name must be specified.
An identifier for a drug at a higher level of abstraction.
Used to uniquely identify a particular drug product when prescribing/dispensing at a higher level of abstraction (e.g. generic drug, generic formulation).
This attribute is marked as "populated" as a drug code should be available in most cases.
The name assigned to the drug at the higher level of abstraction.
To display in dropdowns and for local searching.
This attribute is marked as "populated" as drug name should be available in most cases.
Describes the container in which a drug product can be or should be provided to the patient.

Used for informing dispenser of the need and authorization to dispense medication in a clinically approved container. Aids patients in adhering to administration instructions. May also influence the quantity prescribed.
A coded value denoting a specific kind of a container. Used to identify a requirement for a particular type of compliance packaging
Many insurance plans require that a prescriber specifically authorize the use of compliance packaging before it will be covered by the plan.
Suggested cost of a drug (unit cost).
Allows providers to evaluate patient's affordability status before prescribing a drug.
The average unit dose cost of the drug.
May influence prescriber and pharmacists decisions as cost can impact compliance.
This element is mandatory for DIN-level drugs, not used elsewhere.
Indicates whether the drug is approved for use in Canada or not. (active = approved for use; pending or terminated = not approved for use)
Allows providers to evaluate the validity of the medication for use in Canada.
Indicates the location of a medication in a particular abstract hierarchy. For example, what generic, generic formulation, or therapeutic class does the medication fall into.

Exposes the drug hierarchy, allowing drill-down when prescribing and dispensing. Also indicates possibilities for substitution and can be important for detecting interactions such as allergies or duplicate therapy between closely-related drugs.
A coded value denoting a specific level in the hierarchical definition of drugs.
Describes the relationship between two levels of drug products (e.g. Drug A is the generic for Drug B)
Indicates the physical appearance characteristics of the drug, such as size, color, shape, markings, etc.

Patients are often unfamiliar with the names of their medications, but can describe them by appearance. At the same time, prescribers may be familiar with the name but not the appearance. This information eases communication between provider and patient and also may be used to search for a particular drug product by appearance characteristics.
A list of drugs or raw chemicals that may be present in a manufactured drug or a custom compound.
Important for expressing strength of active ingredients within a drug product, for expressing compound recipes, and for identifying potential causes for adverse reactions.
At least one of ingredient code or ingredient name must be specified.
The unique identifier for the drug or chemical.
Allows un-ambiguous identification of the ingredients of a drug for performing various alert checking.
Also allows for the identification of antigens as class of ingredients in vaccines.
This attribute is marked as "populated" as an ingredient code should be available in most cases.
The name of the contained drug or chemical.
Used for communication between and display to providers.
This attribute is marked as "populated" as an ingredient name should be available in most cases.
Expresses who is responsible for the content of the monograph
Provides a means of evaluating accuracy of the content of the monograph.
Information on the composition and use of a drug.
Guides providers for specifying optimum use of drugs by patients. May also guide patients in appropriately using their medication.
Unique identifier assigned to a medication document record.
Allows matching and replacing of locally-stored medication documents.
This attribute is marked as 'mandatory', as it is always available.

Distinguishes between different kinds of documents and medication documents. Kinds of medication documents include: Clinical Medication document, Patient Education Medication document, Indication Protocol, etc
Allows medication document types to be distinguished for display, printing, etc. Code is mandatory because an application can't know what to do with a medication document without knowing its type.
The date on which the information in the medication document became effective, and/or the date on which the information in the medication document was superseded.

Indicates currency of information or when monograph no longer applies. Different systems may update their monographs at different times, and it is important to know what version contains the most current information
Monograph effective and/or expiry date should be available in most situations and is clinically relevant; thus attribute is marked as 'populated'.

Includes either the full-blown content of the medication document (as a PDF, HTML or HL7 CDA document), or provides a reference to where the medication document can be accessed on the network via HTTP or FTP.
This attribute will also include a coded value denoting the language in which the medication document is written.
Allows delivery of the medication document information to the provider either embedded or by reference.
The inclusion of document language allows providers to determine what language the medication document is written in.
The attribute is mandatory because there is no point in having a medication document with no content.
The name of the organization responsible for creating the medication document.
Helps the receiver evaluate the supplied information.
This is the plan provider (the payor) who is reponsible for evaluating and approving the coverage extension.
Establishes financial responsibility for the prescription as well as provide a means for the provider to engage in follow-up communication with the payor.
The payor for coverage extension must be known, thus this is a mandatory requirement.
Provides additional fill information related to the prescription such as the number of additional fills, if any as well as the fill quantity for each fill.
Device prescriptions may have multiple fills authorized by the original prescription. These additional attributes allow that information to be conveyed.
Identifies the instructions for how the prescribed device should be dispensed to the patient.
An essential part of most prescriptions is the authorization to dispense.
An authorization issued by a payor to cover a device not previously covered by a patient's drug plan.
Allows conveying special coverage information between providers.
If set to 'EVN', then coverage has been granted. Otherwise it has merely been requested.
Indicates to the pharmacy whether they need to check the status of coverage prior to dispensing
Unique identification for a specific coverage extension.
Allows for referencing of a specific coverage extension.
This identifier may be needed on claims against the coverage.
At times the ID will not be available (such as when the request has just been submitted), the attribute is 'populated'.
Indicates any extensions to the patient's insurance coverage that have been solicited by the prescriber, including indications of whether the requested extension was granted.
Helps streamline communication from prescriber to pharmacy by informing the pharmacy of whether an extension has already been requested, and if so, what the status is.
Identifies the address where the dispensed product is to be shipped.
Used when the device cannot/will not be picked up from the dispenser in person.
Information pertaining to a prescriber's authorization for a device to be dispensed to a patient, as well as the instruction on when and how the device is to be used by the patient
This is a 'core' class of the medication model and is important for understanding what devices the patient is intended to be receiving.
The Prescription Order Number is a globally unique number assigned to a prescription by the EHR/DIS irrespective of the source of the order
It is created by the EHR/DIS once the prescription has passed all edits and validation.
Allows for the situations where the order is originating from the DIS.
Allows prescriptions to be uniquely referenced.
Because this attribute is not used for prescriptions originating from a prescriber system, the element is optional.

This denotes the state of the prescription in the lifecycle of the prescription. Valid statuses are: new, active, suspended, aborted, completed, obsolete and nullified. Use 'active' when registering a new prescription or converting a predetermination into a valid prescription.
Indicates what actions are allowed to be performed against a prescription. This is a mandatory field because every prescription needs to be in some state.

Communicates the intent of the patient to restrict access to their prescriptions. Provides support for additional confidentiality constraint, giving patients a level of control over their information.
Valid values are: 'N' (normal - denotes 'Not Masked'); 'R' (restricted - denotes 'Masked') and 'T' (taboo - denotes 'Patient Access Restricted').
The default is 'normal' signifying 'Not Masked'.
Allows the patient to have discrete control over access to their prescription data.
Taboo allows the provider to request restricted access to patient or their care giver.
Constraint: Can’t have both normal and one of the other codes simultaneously.
The attribute is optional because not all systems will support masking.
Indicates the device being prescribed.
This is a key aspect of the prescription and is therefore mandatory
Indicates the pharmacy to which the prescription has been directed or which has currently assumed responsibility for dispensing the prescription.
Allows prescriptions to be directed on the request of the patient or by legal requirement. Also allows indication of which pharmacy is the current 'custodian' of the prescription.
This should always be known or should have an explicit null flavor of 'NA' (non-assigned) or 'UNK' (paper prescription). Thus the association is 'populated'.
The date and time on which the dispense is expected to be picked up.
Allows a prescriber to indicate to the targeted pharmacy, when patient will be expecting to pick up the dispensed device.
The name of the organization responsible for issuing the coverage extension
Mandatory for display purposes.
If present, indicates that the prescription is non-authoritative. I.e. A paper copy must be viewed before the prescription can be dispensed.
Allows distinguishing prescriptions where the paper copy is authoritative vs. the electronic copy being authoritative.
This attribute behaves as a 'mandatory' element where the presence of the association indicates that a paper prescription is needed and the absence of the association indicates that one is not.
Identifies the previous prescription that is being renewed by this order.
Allows tracking a therapy across multiple prescriptions.
A reference to a previous prescription which the current prescription replaces.
Allows a prescription renewal (this prescription) to note the previous prescription id that was renewed;
Allows tracking a therapy across multiple renewal prescriptions.
Indicates how the device should be used by the patient.
Instructions are a key part of the prescription.
Denotes the reason(s) for this specific prescription; it must not be interpreted as a permanent diagnosis.
Helps providers evaluate the appropriateness of the instructions for the device, and may influence education or literature provided to the patient on the use of the device.
Provided at the discretion of the prescriber to enhance patient care.

This field is marked as populated because of its high clinical importance, however 'Nulls' are allowed because the individual recording the prescription (e.g. pharmacist) may not be aware of the indication or the prescriber may choose to withhold (mask) the information due to patient sensitivity.

Ordering of prescribing indications from primary indication (low number) to minor indication (higher number). Multiple indications are permitted to have the same priority if they're considered of equivalent importance.

Allows providers to indicate whether indication is the primary or secondary target of the therapy. E.g., Terazosin for Benign Prostatic Hypertrophy as primary and Hypertension as secondary or vice-versa.
Indicates the location the dispensed device should be shipped to, at the request of the patient or provider.
In some cases devices need to be delivered to the patient instead of being picked up. In other cases, devices need to be shipped to the physician's office to replace stock used for the patient.
Indicates the various comments that providers have recorded about this prescription.
Improves communication between providers by allowing a mechanism to exchange uncoded free-form information.
Allows the prescriber to specify the number of fills authorized by this prescription.
A prescription can authorize multiple fills.
Specifies the quantity for each fill.
The prescription is usually authorized for a specific quantity for each fill.
Specification of how the prescribed device is to be dispensed to the patient. Dispensed instruction information includes the quantity to be dispensed, how often the quantity is to be dispensed, etc.
Sets the parameters within which the dispenser must operate in dispensing the device to the patient.
One of 'quantity' and 'expectedUseTime' must be specified
The overall number of devices to be dispensed under this prescription. Includes any first fills (trials, aligning quantities), the initial standard fill plus all refills.

Sets upper limit for device to be dispensed. Can be used to verify the intention of the prescriber with respect to the overall prescription. Used for comparison when determining whether additional quantity may be dispensed in the context of a part-fill prescription.
The number of days that the overall prescribed item is expected to last, if the patient is compliant with the dispensing and use of the prescription.

Used to specify a total authorization as a duration rather than a quantity with refills. E.g. dispense 30 at a time, refill for 1 year. May also be sent as an estimate of the expected overall duration of the prescription based on the quantity prescribed.
A unique identifier for the payor organization responsible for the coverage extension.
Gives context to the coverage extension identifier and therefore mandatory. Allows the dispensing service delivery location to know where to send a claim.
Information pertaining to a prescriber's authorization for a drug to be dispensed to a patient, as well as the instruction on when and how the drug is to be consumed by the patient
This is a 'core' class of the medication model and is important for understanding what drugs the patient is intended to be receiving.
Id should not be specified if the order is being sent by prescriber; Id is mandatory if the order is being sent by the DIS
The Prescription Order Number is a globally unique number assigned to a prescription by the EHR/DIS irrespective of the source of the order
It is created by the EHR/DIS once the prescription has passed all edits and validation.
Allows for the situations where the order is originating from the DIS.
Allows prescriptions to be uniquely referenced.
Because this attribute is not used for prescriptions originating from a prescriber system, the element is optional.
Indicates that this is a prescription for a drug as opposed to an immunization. For SNOMED, may also contain information regarding drug and route.
Needed to convey the meaning of this class and is therefore mandatory.

This denotes the state of the prescription in the lifecycle of the prescription. Valid statuses are: new, active, suspended, aborted, completed, obsolete and nullified. Use 'new' when submitting a clinical pre-determination. Use 'active' when registering a new prescription or converting a predetermination into a valid prescription.
Indicates what actions are allowed to be performed against a prescription. This is a mandatory field because every prescription needs to be in some state.

Communicates the intent of the patient to restrict access to their prescriptions. Provides support for additional confidentiality constraint, giving patients a level of control over their information.
Valid values are: 'N' (normal - denotes 'Not Masked'); 'R' (restricted - denotes 'Masked') and 'T' (taboo - denotes 'Patient Access Restricted').
The default is 'normal' signifying 'Not Masked'.
Allows the patient to have discrete control over access to their prescription data.
Taboo allows the provider to request restricted access to patient or their care giver.
Constraint: Can’t have both normal and one of the other codes simultaneously.
The attribute is optional because not all systems will support masking.
Identifies the dispense instructions for each drug to be dispensed

Handled as a separate class to allow for multi-drug prescriptions. E.g. 40mg tablets + 50mg tablets. Note that this is NOT intended to combine independent drugs, but rather multiple strengths of the same overall drug.
The association is mandatory because specific supply instructions must be given for at least one medication.
The Prescriber's instruction(s) for the administration of the medication.

This information is needed for a prescription to be valid and is therefore mandatory. Multiple repetitions are supported for circumstances where a single therapy involves the administration of multiple drugs. E.g. Canesten 3 DuoPak.
Enables the indication of whether the prescription is ineligible for trial dispensing.

Serves as reminder for dispenser that the prescription is not to be trial-filled. In some jurisdictions, the prescription must be so designated by the prescriber for the dispenser to do trial dispensing.
An indication that a prescription is or is not eligible for trial dispensing from a clinical (not financial) perspective. False = Eligible, True = Not Eligible.
May affect dispensers' discretion to dispense anything other than prescribed fill quantity.
Expressed as 'Non-Eligibility' rather than 'Eligibility' due to restrictions in HL7 modeling.
The element is mandatory because it must always be known whether the element is true or false.
Indicates the clinical use category in which the prescription has been put.
Allows prescriptions to be categorized in multiple ways.
Identifies the instructions for how the prescribed medication should be dispensed to the patient.

An essential part of most prescriptions is the authorization to dispense. Multiple repetitions are included to accommodate circumstances where multiple drug products may need to be dispensed to complete a therapy. E.g. 100 x 20mg tablets and 50 x 10mg tablets. The association is marked as Populated because the authorization to dispense is a critical portion of a prescription. However the association is allowed to be 'null' when the order is for a medication which requires no dispense authorization (e.g. over-the-counter medications), or when the patient already has sufficient supply of the medication on hand to complete the therapy.
Indicates the expiry date and quantity for the first dispense on the prescription, as well as count-down of refills dispensed.

Used in case of trial prescription or in situations where the first fill may be different from subsequent fills for administrative or non-clinical reasons (e.g. to align the refill dates of a series of prescriptions).
Indicates the total number of fills allowed on this prescription.
This number includes the first fill. Thus, number of refills on the prescription is this number less 1.
Used for compliance checking
This participation is mandatory to ensure that a dispense instruction has at least one fill specification.
An authorization issued by a payor to cover a drug not previously covered by a patient's drug plan.
Allows conveying special coverage information between providers.
If set to 'EVN', then coverage has been granted. Otherwise it has merely been requested.
Indicates to the pharmacy whether they need to check the status of coverage prior to dispensing. The attribute is mandatory due to HL7 rules.
Unique identification for a specific coverage extension.
Allows for referencing of a specific coverage extension.
This identifier may be needed on claims against the coverage.
At times the ID will not be available (such as when the request has just been submitted), the attribute is 'populated'.
Indicates any extensions to the patient's insurance coverage that have been solicited by the prescriber, including indications of whether the requested extension was granted.
Helps streamline communication from prescriber to pharmacy by informing the pharmacy of whether an extension has already been requested, and if so, what the status is.
Enables the communication of a reference to a protocol, study or guideline id, specific to the jurisdiction;
Provides support for non-traditional therapies. Needed when seeking to prescribe “Special Access” medications, for example, Ontario Limited Use.
Identifies the address where the dispensed product is to be shipped.
Used when the medication cannot/will not be picked up from the dispenser in person.
Indicates the medication being prescribed.
This is a key aspect of the medication. It is only 'required' because SNOMED may pre-coordinate the drug into code.
Association is mandatory when not using SNOMED
Special instructions regarding the very first supply of medication to a patient.
Allows a different amount to be dispensed on an initial fill, either as a trial or to synchronize refill dates across multiple patient prescriptions.

The last date before which an initial dispense can be made against the prescription. If an initial fill has not been made against the prescription in this time-period, then the prescription is no longer deemed valid and it may not be dispensed.

Some jurisdictions have distinct stale-date periods for the initial fill of a prescription from the overall dispensing of the prescription. E.g. "The first fill must be made within 1 year, all fills must be complete within 1.5 years". (This attribute would be used for the "1 year").
The quantity of medication to be dispensed the first time the prescription is dispensed against.
Allows a limited quantity to be dispensed for a trial or for a synchronizing dose.
The number of days that the first fill is expected to last, if the patient is compliant with the dispensing of the first fill and with administration of the prescription.
Used when the prescriber cannot or does not wish to calculate the quantity necessary to last for the trial or synchronization time.
Indicates the pharmacy to which the prescription has been directed or which has currently assumed responsibility for dispensing the prescription.
Allows prescriptions to be directed on the request of the patient or by legal requirement. Also allows indication of which pharmacy is the current 'custodian' of the prescription.
This should always be known or should have an explicit null flavor of 'NA' (non-assigned) or 'UNK' (paper prescription). Thus the association is 'populated'.
The date and time on which the dispense is expected to be picked up.
Allows a prescriber to indicate to the targeted pharmacy, when patient will be expecting to pick up the dispensed medication.
Indicates a 'hard' or 'soft' assignment of dispensing priviledged to the targetted facility.
'Hard' assignment (mandated facility) indicates that the prescription can be dispensed only at that facility.
'Soft' assignment (usually as a patient directive) indicates that the prescription may be dispensed at facilities other than the targeted facility.
Influences whether the prescription may be transferred to a service delivery location other than the targeted dispenser.
The name of the organization responsible for issuing the coverage extension
Mandatory for display purposes.
Indicates other patient information that is an important consideration for the prescription. This information is limited to height and weight.
Allows patient height and weight to be conveyed to the pharmacy for dosage calculation or verification
The additional repetitions are to allow for capturing of additional concepts beyond height and weight without impacting the message structure should future versions of the specification allow.
If true, indicates that the prescription is non-authoritative. I.e. A paper copy must be viewed before the prescription can be dispensed.
Allows distinguishing prescriptions where the paper copy is authoritative vs. the electronic copy being authoritative.
This attribute behaves as a 'mandatory' element where the presence of the association indicates that a paper prescription is needed and the absence of the association indicates that one is not.
Identifies the previous prescription that is being renewed by this order.
Allows tracking a therapy across multiple prescriptions.
A reference to a previous prescription which the current prescription replaces.
Allows a prescription renewal (this prescription) to note the previous prescription id that was renewed;
Allows tracking a therapy across multiple renewal prescriptions.
Identifies the drug to be dispensed.
Allows for multiple drugs of the same generic with different strengths to be dispensed to form a single therapy. For example, “Dispense 100 x Drug A (5mg) and 200 x Drug B (10mg)”.
This comprises the height and/or weight of a patient as measured/observed/known by the prescriber at the time of prescribing.
Allows patient height and weight to be conveyed to the pharmacy for dosage calculation or verification;
Identification of the type of measurement/observation that was made about the patient. The only two allowable types are height and weight.
Distinguishes what kind of information is being specified. Code is mandatory to ensure that measurements/observations are distinguishable.
The date on which the measurement was made
Allows providers to evaluate currency of the information.
Because the date of measurement determines the relevance of the information, this attribute is defined as 'populated'.
The amount (quantity and unit) that has been recorded for the specific type of observation. E.g. height in meters, weight in kilograms.
Provides comparable representation of the measurement. May be used in calculations.
Attribute is defined as 'mandatory' to ensure that a value is supplied, if there is a measurement.
Denotes the reason(s) for this specific prescription; it must not be interpreted as a permanent diagnosis.
Helps providers evaluate the appropriateness of the dosage instructions for the medication, and may influence education or literature provided to the patient on the use of the medication.
Provided at the discretion of the prescriber to enhance patient care. E.g., take 1 tab bid for migraine. Also needed for drug-disease interaction checking software to work properly.

This field is marked as populated because of its high clinical importance, however 'Nulls' are allowed because the individual recording the prescription (e.g. pharmacist) may not be aware of the indication or the prescriber may choose to withhold (mask) the information due to patient sensitivity.

Ordering of prescribing indications from primary indication (low number) to minor indication (higher number). Multiple indications are permitted to have the same priority if they're considered of equivalent importance.

Allows providers to indicate whether indication is the primary or secondary target of the therapy. E.g., Terazosin for Benign Prostatic Hypertrophy as primary and Hypertension as secondary or vice-versa.
Identifies the person(s) other than the patient, who are authorized to pick up the medication.
Used when patient is not in a position to pick up medication and when alternate receivers must be specifically authorized (e.g. for narcotics).
Repetitions are specified to allow for any one of multiple agents of the patient (e.g. Mother, Father, Cousin, Friend, etc) to be designated as allowed to pick up dispensed drugs.
Indicates the location the dispensed medication should be shipped to, at the request of the patient or provider.
In some cases drugs need to be delivered to the patient instead of being picked up. In other cases, drugs need to be shipped to the physician's office to replace stock used for the patient.

Indicates whether the prescriber wishes to restrict the ability of the dispenser to make substitutions in selecting the specific drug to dispense. If not specified, substitutions are allowed, at the professional discretion of the dispenser or mandated through legislation.
May have financial implications for the patient. Many plans will not pay for name-brand medications unless the prescriber has indicated to the dispenser that substitutions are not permitted.
Indicates the various comments that providers have recorded about this prescription.
Improves communication between providers by allowing a mechanism to exchange uncoded free-form information.
Indicates a minimum amount of time that must occur between dispenses.
Helps the prescriber ensure that the patient does not ever receive more than the appropriate amount of medication in a particular timeframe.
The number of times the prescribed quantity is to be dispensed including the initial standard fill.
Used to calculate total prescribed quantity; and also used for compliance checking.
Expressed as Number of Fills rather than number of refills due to HL7 modeling constraints.
The amount of medication to be dispensed to the patient for each normal fill (excluding trial or other special first fills).
Limits the quantity of medication in patient's possession at a time. Used in compliance checking.

The number of days that each standard fill is expected to last. The dispenser must use the administration instructions together with the Days Supply to calculate the total quantity to dispense per fill. May be specified in addition to quantity to indicate the length of time a quantity of "as needed" medication is expected to last.

Useful in determining and managing certain contraindications ('Fill-Too-Soon', 'Fill-Too-Late', and 'Duration of Therapy'). Also provides guidance to the pharmacy on how much to dispense. Also useful in research
A unique identifier for a specific protocol or guideline which the prescription has been written in accordance with.
Enables the communication of a reference to a protocol, study or guideline id, specific to the jurisdiction;

Allows providers to reference a protocol/guideline for prescribing to specific situations. This could also be used for justification for prescribing a medication from a particular formulary. E.g., 'Limited Use' medications in Ontario require physicians to use a code indicating that a patient is eligible for this particular medication;
This attribute is mandatory as the id clearly identifies the protocol, study or guideline being referenced
A prescriber's instruction that a specific prescribed product be dispensed as is, or not.
May have financial and therapeutic conformance ramifications for a patient.
If true, indicates that the prescriber has prohibited substitution. Default is that substitution is allowed.
Indicates whether substitutions are allowed. The attribute is mandatory because whether substitution is allowed must be declared.
The reason why the prescriber has indicated that substitution is not allowed by the dispensing pharmacy.

Some jurisdictions demand that a prescriber gives a reason for prohibiting substitution. The field is marked as 'Populated' because the reason for substitution is important to understanding the decision. However when a prescription is being recorded in the pharmacy, the information may not be available.

Specification of how the prescribed medication is to be dispensed to the patient. Dispensed instruction information includes the quantity to be dispensed, how often the quantity is to be dispensed, etc.
Sets the parameters within which the dispenser must operate in dispensing the medication to the patient.
This indicates the validity period of a prescription (stale dating the Prescription).

It reflects the prescriber perspective for the validity of the prescription. Dispenses must not be made against the prescription outside of this period. The lower-bound of the Prescription Effective Period signifies the earliest date that the prescription can be filled for the first time. If an upper-bound is not specified then the Prescription is open-ended or will default to a stale-date based on regulations.
Indicates when the Prescription becomes valid, and when it ceases to be a dispensable Prescription.
Some jurisdictions place a 'stale date' on prescriptions that cause them to become invalid a certain amount of time after they are written. This time may vary by medication.
Specification of the overall use duration of the prescrbed medication and/or overall quantity to be dispensed.
Sets the parameters within which the dispenser must operate in dispensing the medication to the patient.
The overall amount of amount medication to be dispensed under this prescription. Includes any first fills (trials, aligning quantities), the initial standard fill plus all refills.

Sets upper limit for medication to be dispensed. Can be used to verify the intention of the prescriber with respect to the overall medication. Used for comparison when determining whether additional quantity may be dispensed in the context of a part-fill prescription.
Narcotics must always be specified as a total.
The number of days that the overall prescribed item is expected to last, if the patient is compliant with the dispensing and administration of the prescription.

Used to specify a total authorization as a duration rather than a quantity with refills. E.g. dispense 30 at a time, refill for 1 year. May also be sent as an estimate of the expected overall duration of the prescription based on the quantity prescribed.
This attribute is mandatory because the prescriber (in discussion with the patient) has a better understanding of the days supply needed by the patient.
A unique identifier for the payor organization responsible for the coverage extension.
Gives context to the coverage extension identifier and therefore mandatory. Allows the dispensing service delivery location to know where to send a claim.
Describes the categorization of the therapy envisioned by this prescription (e.g. Continuous/Chronic, Short-Term/Acute and "As-Needed).

Allows categorizing prescription for presentation. May influence detection of duplicate therapy. May also be used to affect how DUR processing is completed. The code is mandatory as this information should be known at prescribe time.

This is an identifier assigned to a specific medication order. The number remains constant across the lifetime of the order, regardless of the number of providers or pharmacies involved in fulfilling the order.
Allows prescriptions to be uniquely referenced. Multiple identifiers are allowed to support assigning of prescription ids by the prescriber, EHR, and potentially by pharmacies.
The ID is mandatory to allow every prescription record to be uniquely identified.
Indicates any remaining dispense quantity associated with the prescription.

Allows updating the remaining dispense quantity at the time the prescription is transferred. Multiple repetitions are allowed for those circumstances where the prescription orders multiple drugs (e.g. 10mg tablets plus 40mg tablets).
Indicates the pharmacy to which the prescription is to be assigned.
Use N/A for prescriptions controlled by the DIS and Unknown for prescriptions being transferred to paper.
Allows the prescription to be transferred to another pharmacy or back to the DIS. The association is marked as 'populated' because a specific null flavor is needed if no facility is identified
If true, indicates that the prescription is non-authoritative. I.e. A paper copy must be viewed before the prescription can be dispensed.
Allows distinguishing prescriptions where the paper copy is authoritative vs. the electronic copy being authoritative.
This attribute behaves as a 'mandatory' element where the presence of the association indicates that a paper prescription is needed and the absence of the association indicates that one is not.
Must not be used for the transfer of device prescription
Product only needs to be specified when multiple drugs are part of the same order (e.g. 10mg tablets + 40mg tablets). Each repetition must refer to a distinct drug product.
Indicates dispenses yet to be made against the prescription
Allows updating the quantity remaining to be dispensed.
Indicates the remaining quantity to be dispensed.
The specified remaining fill quantity may never be greater than the remaining quantity recorded in the electronic system. If not specified, the quantity remaining will be left unchanged.

Used to adjust quantity asserted with the electronic version of a prescription when fills have been issued by non-electronic pharmacies. Particularly important when the electronic version is being made 'authoritative' again.
This is the information that describes the authorization for a dispenser to dispense the prescription.
Sets the parameters within which the dispenser must operate.
Used when patient is not in a position to pick up medication and when alternate receivers must be specifically authorized (e.g. for narcotics).
Identifies the person(s) other than the patient, who picked up the medication.
Captures information about what prescription was picked up and who received it.
The root class for the message. The time of pickup is specified on the ControlAct wrapper.
Identity of prescription dispense that has been picked up.
Allows dispenses to be uniquely identified. This attribute is mandatory because the identity of the dispense record must be known.
Information pertaining to a prescriber's authorization for a drug to be dispensed to a patient, as well as the instruction on when and how the drug is to be administered to the patient.
This is a 'core' class of the medication model and is important for understanding what drugs the patient is intended to be receiving. Also needed for e-prescribing.

This is an identifier assigned to a specific medication order. The number remains constant across the lifetime of the order, regardless of the number of providers or pharmacies involved in fulfilling the order.
Allows prescriptions to be uniquely referenced. Multiple identifiers are allowed to support assigning of prescription ids by the prescriber, EHR, and potentially by pharmacies.
The ID is mandatory to allow every prescription record to be uniquely identified.
Represents the information returned when a dispense has been accepted
Allows communication of the identifiers assigned to the dispense and the prescription by the DIS.
Identifier of a dispense event to be used by the requesting dispenser.
Establishes a record of impending dispense on the prescription. Attribute is mandatory to ensure that successful request to dispense has been acknowledged by the DIS.
The person who ordered the office supply.
Used to create an 'inferred' prescription if an electronic prescription does not already exist in the EHR.
The attribute is marked as "populated" as the prescriber must be known or null flavour specified.
Indicates what facility the medication was dispensed to.
Allows tracking what drugs are dispensed to a facility.
Indicates the prescription that is being dispensed against.
Links the dispense act to the prescription order it was performed against.
Identifies the product being dispensed.
Also provides information on compound ingredients and instructions and packaging requirements
The drug being supplied must be identified and and is therefore mandatory.
Identity of the provider who is taking responsibility for the actions of the author.
Allows for the trail of responsibility for the action.
The location where the supply is expected to be delivered.
Allows tracking what drugs are dispensed to a facility.
Identifier of the facility where the dispensed medication was shipped.
Allows tracking what drugs are dispensed to a facility. The attribute is mandatory because identification of the facility must be known.
Indicates the various comments that providers have recorded about this office supply.
Improves communication between providers by allowing a mechanism to exchange un-coded free-form information.
This is the detailed information about a medication being supplied for office use.
Allows for tracking of medications supplied to an office.
Identifier assigned by the dispensing facility.
Allows formal tracking of centrally recorded dispenses to local records for audit and related purposes.
Indicates the type of dispensing event that is being performed.
This is a fixed dispense type of 'Office Supply' unless using SNOMED.
Indicates reason for the size of dispense. Because it defines what type of dispense is occurring, the attribute is mandatory.
Represents the date medication was supplied.
Must be able to post date a dispense (enter retroactively) e.g. system failure
Needed for audit purposes.
Because the supply date is always known, the attribute is mandatory.
The amount of medication that has been dispensed. Includes unit of measure.
Allows for auditing of medication dispensed to an office. This is mandatory to allow reconciliation with the amount used from the office.
Identification of the supply information. This prescription will have a supply order portion but no administration part.
Ensures that dispenses to offices (non-patient identifiable dispenses) follow the normal dispensing rules.
The person who prescribed the device.
Used to create an 'inferred' prescription if an electronic prescription does not already exist in the EHR.

The calendar date on which the device was prescribed. This may differ from the date on which the prescription becomes effective. E.g. A prescription created today may not be valid to be dispensed or used for two weeks.
Indicates when the action was performed, and may influence expiry dates for the order.
The attribute is populated because the creation date of the prescription shall always be known or absent for a reason.
Indicates the days supply and quantity of devices dispensed.
Dispense is not complete without specifying quantity dispensed, and thus this association is mandatory.
Identification of the facility/location where the device was shipped to, as part of the dispense event.
Indicates how the device was delivered to the patient.
This is the detailed information about a device dispense that has been performed on behalf a patient
Dispensing is an integral part of the overall prescription process.
Identifier assigned by the dispensing facility.
Allows formal tracking of centrally recorded dispenses to local records for audit and related purposes.
Communicates the intent that the dispense should be masked if it is created; If the dispense is masked, this makes the complete prescription and all dispenses masked.
If a dispense is masked, it implicitly masks the prescription being dispensed. (There's no point in masking a dispense if the prescription is unmasked.)
Can be used to set a mask for a new dispense, if present in a new dispense request.
Allows the patient to have discrete control over access to their prescription data.
Taboo allows the provider to request restricted access to patient or their care giver.
Constraint: Can’t have both normal and one of the other codes simultaneously.
The attribute is optional because not all systems will support masking.
Information pertaining to the prescription for which a dispense is being created
Dispenses for electronically created prescriptions must reference the prescription.
The Prescriber Name must be specified only when the Prescription ID is Null
The identifier of the prescription for which a dispense is beiing created.
Allows prescriptions to be uniquely referenced.
The ID is only 'populated' because in some cases the prescription will not yet exist electronically.
Indicates the prescription that is being dispensed against.
Links the dispense act to the prescription order it was performed against.
Indicates how the patient is expected to use the device.
Communicates to other providers how the patient is expected to use the dispensed device
Identifies the product being dispensed.
Identifies the device as part of the patient's profile. The device is one of the most important parts of the dispense record, and it is therefore mandatory.
Identity of the provider who is taking responsibilty for the actions of the author.
Allows for the trail of responsibility for the action.
The location where the dispensed product is expected to be delivered.
Important as part of a claim for justifying shipping charges.
Indicates where the dispensed product was sent.
Important as part of a claim for justifying shipping charges.
Indicates the various comments that providers make about a particular prescription dispense.
Improves communication between providers by allowing a mechanism to exchange un-coded free-form information.
Indicates the patient the device was dispensed for.
Indicates the patient record the dispense event should attached to. Because of this, the association is mandatory.
Indicates the type of dispensing event that is performed. Examples include: Trial Fill, Completion of Trial, Partial Fill, Emergency Fill, Samples, etc.
Indicates reason for the size of dispense. Because it defines what type of dispense is occurring, the attribute is mandatory.

Represents the date the dispense product was prepared and when the product was picked up by or delivered to the patient. The dispense processing date and pickup date can be back dated to reflect when the actual processing and pickup occurred. The lower-bound of the period signifies the dispense-processing date whereas the upper-bound signifies the dispense-pickup date.
Must be able to post-date a dispense (enter retroactively) e.g. system failure.

Used by the system in calculating expected exhaustion time. Valuable in compliance checking. This attribute is mandatory because an existing dispense record must at least indicate the date it was processed.
The number of devices that have been dispensed.
Critical in understanding the patient's profile, both past and current, This is also mandatory to allow determination of the amount that remains to be dispensed against the prescription.
The number of days that the dispensed quantity is expected to last.

Useful in monitoring patient compliance. May also be useful in determining and managing certain contraindications ('Fill-Too-Soon', 'Fill-Too-Late', and 'Duration of Therapy'). Because 'Days Supply' may be necessary to compute total dispensed quantity, it is made a 'populated' field.
invariant( x) { The identifier must be either the patient identifier, the prescriber identifier or the dispenser identifier. }
Identity of the person who ultimately made the substitution decision.
Provides a trace of responsibility for the substitution.
The person who prescribed the medication.
Used to create an 'inferred' prescription if an electronic prescription does not already exist in the EHR.

The date at which the drug was prescribed. This may differ from the date on which the prescription becomes effective. E.g. A prescription created today may not be valid to be dispensed or administered for two weeks.
Indicates when the action was performed, and may influence expiry dates for the order.
The attribute is populated because the creation date of the prescription shall always be known or absent for a reason.
Indicates the days supply and quantity of medication dispensed.
Dispense is not complete without specifying quantity dispensed, and thus this association is mandatory.
Indicates how the drug is to be consumed by the patient.
It is important to understand the specific instructions that were provided to the patient. Therefore, the association is mandatory.
Indicates whether or not substitution was made as part of the dispense.
Must be consistent with substitution directive from the prescription.
Identification of the facility/location where the drug was shipped to, as part of the dispense event.
Indicates how the medication was delivered to the patient.
Indicates the prescription that is being dispensed against.
Links the dispense act to the prescription order it was performed against.
This is the detailed information about a medication dispense that has been performed on behalf a patient.
Dispensing is an integral part of the overall medication process.
Identifier assigned by the dispensing facility.
Allows formal tracking of centrally recorded dispenses to local records for audit and related purposes.
Communicates the intent that the dispense should be masked if it is created; If the dispense is masked, this makes the complete prescription and all dispenses masked.
If a dispense is masked, it implicitly masks the prescription being dispensed. (There's no point in masking a dispense if the prescription is unmasked.)
Can be used to set a mask for a new dispense, if present in a new dispense request.
Allows the patient to have discrete control over access to their prescription data.
Taboo allows the provider to request restricted access to patient or their care giver.
Constraint: Can’t have both normal and one of the other codes simultaneously.
The attribute is optional because not all systems will support masking.
Identifies the product being dispensed.
Also provides information on compound ingredients and instructions and packaging requirements
Identifies the drug as part of the patient's medication profile. The drug is one of the most important parts of the dispense record, and it is therefore mandatory.
Indicates the person who was responsible for making the substitution decision (e.g. prescriber, dispenser, patient).
Who made the substitution decision may affect the decision of how much to reimburse
Identity of the provider who is taking responsibility for the actions of the author.
Allows for the trail of responsibility for the action.
The location where the dispensed product is expected to be delivered.
Important as part of a claim for justifying shipping charges.
Indicates where the dispensed product was sent.
Important as part of a claim for justifying shipping charges.
Indicates the various comments that providers make about a particular prescription dispense.
Improves communication between providers by allowing a mechanism to exchange un-coded free-form information.
Indicates the patient the drug was dispensed for.
Indicates the patient record the dispense event should attached to. Because of this, the association is mandatory.
Information pertaining to the prescription for which a dispense is being created
Dispenses for electronically created prescriptions must reference the prescription.
The Prescriber Name must be specified only when the Prescription Order Number is Null.
Component MUST be specified if the id is null and CAN NOT be specified if the id is not null
The identifier of the prescription for which a dispense is being created.
Allows prescriptions to be uniquely referenced.
The ID is only 'populated' because in some cases the prescription will not yet exist electronically.
An indication of what kind of substitution was made, if any.
May explain why prescribed and dispensed medications may differ.
A code signifying whether a different drug was dispensed from what was prescribed.
Indicates that substitution was done (or not). This attribute is mandatory because it is essential to understanding the substitution.
Indicates the reason for the substitution of (or lack of substitution) from what was prescribed.
Standardized reasons for substitution performed (or not performed). Useful in analysis of dispensing patterns.
Indicates the type of dispensing event that is performed. Examples include: Trial Fill, Completion of Trial, Partial Fill, Emergency Fill, Samples, etc.
Indicates reason for the size of dispense. Because it defines what type of dispense is occurring, the attribute is mandatory.

Represents the date the dispense product was prepared and when the product was picked up by or delivered to the patient. The dispense processing date and pickup date can be back dated to reflect when the actual processing and pickup occurred. The lower-bound of the period signifies the dispense-processing date whereas the upper-bound signifies the dispense-pickup date.
Must be able to post-date a dispense (enter retroactively) e.g. system failure.

Used by the system in calculating expected exhaustion time. Valuable in compliance checking. This attribute is mandatory because an existing dispense record must at least indicate the date it was processed.
The amount of medication that has been dispensed. Includes unit of measure.
Critical in understanding the patient's medication profile, both past and current, This is also mandatory to allow determination of the amount that remains to be dispensed against the prescription.
The number of days that the dispensed quantity is expected to last.

Useful in monitoring patient compliance. May also be useful in determining and managing certain contraindications ('Fill-Too-Soon', 'Fill-Too-Late', and 'Duration of Therapy'). Because 'Days Supply' may be necessary to compute total dispensed quantity, it is made a 'populated' field.
The overall amount of amount medication to be dispensed under this prescription. Includes any first fills (trials, aligning quantities), the initial standard fill plus all refills.
Critical in understanding the patient's medication profile, both past and current. This also allows determination of the amount that remains to be dispensed against the prescription.
The number of days that the overall prescribed item is expected to last, if the patient is compliant with the dispensing and administration of the prescription.
Useful in monitoring patient compliance. May also be useful in determining and managing certain contraindications ('Fill-Too-Soon', 'Fill-Too-Late', and 'Duration of Therapy').
A free form textual specification generated from the input specifications as created by the provider.

This is made up of either an 'Ad-hoc dosage instruction' or 'Textual rendition of the structured dosage lines', plus route, dosage unit, and other pertinent administration information specified by the provider.
Allows the provider to verify the codified structured dosage information entered and ensure that the exploded instruction is consistent with the intended instructions.
Also useful in bringing back administration instructions on query responses. Because all prescriptions and dispenses have dosage, this attribute is mandatory.
Indicates who refused to fulfill the prescription
Allows follow-up and traceability of the refusal and is therefore mandatory.
This is the provider who authorized the medication to be dispensed to the patient.
To be a legal order, the person responsible for its creation must be identified. Thus the association is mandatory.

The date at which the drug was prescribed/dispensed. This may differ from the date on which the prescription becomes effective. E.g. A prescription created today may not be valid to be dispensed or administered for two weeks.
Indicates when the action was performed, and may influence expiry dates for the order.
The attribute is populated because the creation date of the prescription will not always be known (as in the case of 'inferred prescription').
Where the prescription is for a combination of drugs (e.g. 10mg tablets + 40mg tablets) repeatNumber cannot be populated and quantity must be expressed in mg.
This is a 'core' class of the medication model and is important for understanding what drugs the patient is intended to be receiving.
The Prescription Order Number is a globally unique number assigned to a prescription by the EHR/DIS irrespective of the source of the order
It is created by the EHR/DIS once the prescription has passed all edits and validation.
Allows prescriptions to be uniquely referenced.
The number is mandatory to allow every prescription record to be uniquely identified.
Indicates that this is a prescription for a drug as opposed to an immunization. For SNOMED, may also contain information regarding drug and route.
Needed to convey the meaning of this class and is therefore mandatory.
The element allows 'CD' to provide support for SNOMED.
This denotes the state of the prescription in the lifecycle of the prescription. Valid statuses are: NEW, ACTIVE, SUSPENDED, ABORTED, COMPLETED, OBSOLETE and NULLIFIED.
Indicates what actions are allowed to be performed against a prescription.
This is a mandatory field because every prescription needs to be in some state.
Communicates the intent of the patient to restrict access to their prescriptions.
Provides support for additional confidentiality constraint, giving patients a level of control over their information.
Valid values are: 'N' (normal - denotes 'Not Masked'); 'R' (restricted - denotes 'Masked') and 'T' (taboo - denotes 'Patient Access Restricted').
The default is 'normal' signifying 'Not Masked'.
Allows the patient to have discrete control over access to their medication data.
Taboo allows the provider to request restricted access to patient or their care giver.
Constraint: Can’t have both normal and one of the other codes simultaneously.
The attribute is required because even if a jurisdiction doesn't support masking on the way in, it will need to need to communicate masked data returned from other jurisdictions.
Associates the event with other care events
Allows for grouping the current event with other care events.
The Prescriber's instruction(s) for the administration of the medication.

This information is needed for a prescription to be valid and is therefore mandatory. Multiple repetitions are supported for circumstances where a single therapy involves the administration of multiple drugs. E.g. Didrocal.
Indicates the clinical use category in which the prescription has been put.
Allows prescriptions to be categorized in multiple ways.
Identifies the instructions for how the prescribed medication should be dispensed to the patient.

An essential part of most prescriptions is the authorization to dispense. Multiple repetitions are included to accommodate circumstances where multiple drug products may need to be dispensed to complete a therapy. E.g. 100 x 20mg tablets and 50 x 10mg tablets. The association is marked as Populated because the authorization to dispense is a critical portion of a prescription. However the association is allowed to be 'null' when the order is for a medication which requires no dispense authorization (e.g. over-the-counter medications), or when the patient already has sufficient supply of the medication on hand to complete the therapy.
If true, indicates that the data associated with the prescription is uncertain because the existence of the prescription has been inferred from a secondary source (e.g. dispensing data).

Distinguishes electronic records which reflect exactly what was ordered from orders that merely mimic what was dispensed and therefore can't be used for information about ordering patterns. Because it must always be known how an order was captured, this attribute is mandatory.
Describes an issue associated with a prescription that resulted in a dispenser refusing to fill it.
Allows a dispenser to assert an issue against a prescription to be displayed to subsequent dispensers as well as others reviewing the patient's medication profile.

A coded value that is used to distinguish between different kinds of issues. Types of issue include: unrecognized identifiers, permission issues, drug-drug contraindications, drug-allergy alerts, duplicate therapies, suspect fraud etc.
Identifies what kind of issue was detected or is being managed.
This is mandatory so as to ensure that one issue type can be distinguished from another.
A free form textual description regarding the issue of fraudulence. This may be specified in place of, or in addition to the coded issue.
Enables extra or more detailed description of the alert
The presence of issues can be of clinical significance and may prompt a clinician to wish to drill down for further information.
Indicates the medication that has been prescribed to the patient.
This is a key aspect of the prescription. It is only marked as 'required' because SNOMED may pre-coordinate the drug into code.
Association is mandatory when not using SNOMED
Provides summary information about future dispenses.
Helps provide an overview of the prescription.
Provides summary information about future dispenses.
Helps provide an overview of the prescription.
Provides summary information about the first dispense made on the prescription.
Helps provide an overview of the prescription.
Provides summary information about the most recent dispense on the prescription.
Helps provide an overview of the prescription.
Identifies the location where the refusal occurred
Allows follow-up and traceability of the refusal and is therefore mandatory
Indicates the pharmacy to which the prescription has been directed or which has currently assumed responsibility for dispensing the prescription.
Allows prescriptions to be directed on the request of the patient or by legal requirement. Also allows indication of which pharmacy is the current 'custodian' of the prescription.
This should always be known or should have an explicit null flavor of 'NA' (non-assigned) or 'UNK' (paper prescription). Thus the association is 'populated'.
Indicates a 'hard' or 'soft' assignment of dispensing priviledged to the targetted facility.
'Hard' assignment (mandated facility) indicates that the prescription can be dispensed only at that facility.
'Soft' assignment (usually as a patient directive) indicates that the prescription may be dispensed at facilities other than the targeted facility.
Influences whether the prescription may be transferred to a service delivery location other than the targeted dispenser.
If true, indicates that the prescription is non-authoritative. I.e. A paper copy must be viewed before the prescription can be dispensed.
Allows distinguishing prescriptions where the paper copy is authoritative vs. the electronic copy being authoritative.
This attribute behaves as a 'mandatory' element where the presence of the association indicates that a paper prescription is needed and the absence of the association indicates that one is not.
Denotes the reason(s) for this specific prescription; it must not be interpreted as a permanent diagnosis.
Helps providers evaluate the appropriateness of the dosage instructions for the medication, and may influence education or literature provided to the patient on the use of the medication.
Provided at the discretion of the prescriber to enhance patient care. E.g., take 1 tab bid for migraine. Also needed for drug-disease interaction checking software to work properly.

This field is marked as populated because of its high clinical importance, however 'Nulls' are allowed because the individual recording the prescription (e.g. pharmacist) may not be aware of the indication or the prescriber may choose to withhold (mask) the information due to patient sensitivity.

Ordering of prescribing indications from primary indication (low number) to minor indication (higher number). Multiple indications are permitted to have the same priority if they're considered of equivalent importance.

Allows providers to indicate whether indication is the primary or secondary target of the therapy. E.g., Terazosin for Benign Prostatic Hypertrophy as primary and Hypertension as secondary or vice-versa.
Identifies an issue as the reason for recording a refusal to fill against a prescription.
Allows a dispenser to point to an issue of 'suspect fraud' as the reason for recording a 'refusal to fill' against a prescription.
Indicates that the identified issue resulted in a dispenser refusing to fill the subject prescription.
Exposes in the model that this issue is associated with a refusal to dispense.
An indication of 'refusal to fill' must be indicated, thus attribute is mandatory.
One of 'Refusal To Fill Reason' or 'Issue' must be specified, but not both.
The date that the dispenser refused to fill the prescitpion
May be important to down stream providers to know when the refusal occured.
Is marked as populated as it may not always be known for historical data pre- loaded into the EHR
Indicates a non-clinical-issue based reason for refusing to fill.
Indicates a non-clinical-issue based reason for refusing to fill. Allows CWE for non-coded reasons.
Identity of the provider who is taking responsibility for the actions of the author.
Allows for the trail of responsibility for the action.
If present, indicates that there are notes associated with the drug prescription.
Shows whether additional information is available on further drill-down
This association is mandatory as it indicates one of presence or absence notes.
Indicates that there are issues associated with this prescription.
The presence of issues can be of clinical significance and may prompt a clinician to wish to drill down for further information.
This association is mandatory as it indicates one of presence or absence issues.
Indicates refusals that have been recorded against the prescription
Makes information about prior refusals to subsequent pharmacies, as well as to the prescriber
Provides summary information about the first dispense event on the prescription
Useful in understanding the status of a prescription and in planning for renewals.
Indicates when the first dispense against the prescription was picked up.
Useful in establishing start of therapy.
Important information for compliance.
Indicates the amount of medication first dispensed on the prescription.
Usually establishes trial quantities for a prescription.
If the first dispense information is known, the quantity must be known and therefore is mandatory
Provides summary information about what dispenses remain to be performed against the prescription
Useful in understanding the status of a prescription and in planning for renewals.
At least one of quantity and repeatNumber must be specified.
Indicates the number of remaining dispenses estimated, assuming that each fill is equal to the quantity prescribed for a single fill, rounding up.
Indicates the number of dispenses that may still occur.
Indicates the total remaining undispensed quantity authorized against the prescription.
Indicates how much can still be dispensed.
Provides summary information about the most recent dispense event performed against the prescription
Useful in understanding the status of a prescription and in planning for renewals.
Indicates the most recent date on which a dispense on the prescription was picked up.
Useful in determining when a prescription will next need to be dispensed. Also provides an indication of compliance.
Indicates the most recent quantity of the drug that was picked up for the prescription.
Useful in determining amount of medication that a patient should have on-hand. Also provides an indication of compliance.
If the most recent dispense information is known, the quantity must be known and therefore is mandatory
Summarizes the dispenses that have happened against the prescription to date.
Helps in understanding the status of the prescription and evaluating compliance.
At least one of quantity and repeatNumber must be specified.

documentation.businessName: A:Number of Fill Made Against Rx
documentation.p: Indicates the number of dispense events performed against the prescription to date, including trial, partial and complete fills.
Useful in tracking the progress of a prescription in prescription.
Indicates the amount of the prescribed medication that has been dispensed to-date.
Useful for tracking the progress of a prescription

Specification of how the prescribed medication is to be dispensed to the patient. Dispensed instruction information includes the quantity to be dispensed, how often the quantity is to be dispensed, etc.
Sets the parameters within which the dispenser must operate in dispensing the medication to the patient.

This generally mirrors the status for the prescription, but in some circumstances may be changed to 'aborted' while the prescription is still active. When this occurs, it means the prescription may no longer be dispensed, though it may still be administered.
Allows a prescriber to say "Finish what you have on hand, but don't get any more."
Because the status should always be known, this element is mandatory.
The overall amount of amount medication to be dispensed under this prescription. Includes any first fills (trials, aligning quantities), the initial standard fill plus all refills.

Sets upper limit for medication to be dispensed. Can be used to verify the intention of the prescriber with respect to the overall medication. Used for comparison when determining whether additional quantity may be dispensed in the context of a part-fill prescription.
Narcotics must always be specified as a total quantity.
Categorization of prescriptions based on the intended duration of the prescribed therapy.
Useful in establishing compliance for drug renewals and refills.
Describes the categorization of the therapy envisioned by this prescription (e.g. Continuous/Chronic, Short-Term/Acute and "As-Needed).
Allows categorizing prescription for presentation. May influence detection of duplicate therapy. May also be used to affect how DUR processing is completed.
The field is marked mandatory because the intended duration of the therapy should be known at prescribe time.
Indicates how the drug is to be consumed by the patient.
When available, it is important to understand the specific instructions that were provided to the patient.
Identifies the other active medication being recorded into the system as being taken by the patient.
The drug is the key part of this recording activity, and is therefore mandatory.

A record of a medication the patient is believed to be taking, but for which an electronic order does not exist. 'Other medications' include any drug product deemed relevant to the patient's drug profile, but which was not specifically ordered by a prescriber in a DIS-enabled jurisdiction. Examples include over-the counter medications that were not specifically ordered, herbal remedies, and recreational drugs. Prescription drugs that the patient may be taking but were not prescribed on the EHR (e.g. institutionally administered or out-of-jurisdiction prescriptions) will also be recorded here.
Necessary component of a person's overall medication profile. Allows DUR checking against a more complete drug profile.
Status can only be 'ACTIVE' or 'COMPLETED'
routeCode must not be used when code is SNOMED and is mandatory otherwise
Indicates that the record is a drug administration rather than an immunization or other type of administration. For SNOMED, may also include route, drug and other information.
Needed to convey the meaning of this class and is therefore mandatory.
The element allows 'CD' to provide support for SNOMED.
Must be 'DRUG' unless using SNOMED
This denotes a state in the lifecycle of the other medication. Valid statuses are: 'ACTIVE' and 'COMPLETED' only.
Indicates what actions are allowed to be performed against an other medication record. This is a mandatory field because every recorded 'other medication' needs to be in some state.

Note ------ The provider might know that the patient is not taking the medication but not necessarily when the patient stopped it. Thus the status of the medication could be set to 'COMPLETED' by the provider without necessarily setting an End Date on the medication record.
Indicates the time-period in which the patient has been taking or is expected to be taking the medication.
Either the start or end or both can be null if they are not known.
Used to help determine whether the medication is currently active. Because this information won't always be available, the attribute is marked as 'populated'.
Denotes access restriction place on the other medication record. Methods for accessing masked other medications will be governed by each jurisdiction (e.g. court orders, shared secret/consent, etc.).
Provides support for additional confidentiality constraint to reflect the wishes of the patient.
Taboo allows the provider to request restricted access to patient or their care giver.
Constraint: Can’t have both normal and one of the other codes simultaneously.
The attribute is optional because not all systems will support masking.
This is the means by which the patient is taking the other medication.

Ensures consistency in description of routes. Provides potential for cross-checking dosage form and route. Because this information is pre-coordinated into 'code' for SNOMED, it is marked as optional.
Comments made by provider on the medication.
Allows the recording of additional information on the medication being taken by the patient.
While SNOMED codes may pre-coordinate the drug code, the drug must not be modified. However route information for a drug may be updated.
The medication record being updated.
routeCode must not be used when code is SNOMED and is mandatory otherwise
Identifier of the Other Medication record that needs to be updated.
Uniquely identifies the record to be updated and is therefore mandatory.
Indicates that the record is a drug administration rather than an immunization or other type of administration. For SNOMED, may also include route, drug and other information.
Needed to convey the meaning of this class and is therefore mandatory.
The element allows 'CD' to provide support for SNOMED.
Must be 'DRUG' unless using SNOMED
Indicates whether the medication is still considered active.
Valid status can only be 'ACTIVE' or 'COMPLETED'.
Indicates the new state of the medication and is therefore mandatory.

Note ------ The provider might know that the patient is not taking the medication but not necessarily when the patient stopped it. Thus the status of the medication could be set to 'COMPLETED' by the provider without necessarily setting an End Date on the medication record.
The new period in which the active medication is deemed to be active.
Allows the drug active period information to be changed.
Taboo allows the provider to request restricted access to patient or their care giver.
Constraint: Can’t have both normal and one of the other codes simultaneously.
Taboo allows the provider to request restricted access to patient or their care giver.
Constraint: Can’t have both normal and one of the other codes simultaneously.
This is the means by which the patient is taking the other medication.

Ensures consistency in description of routes. Provides potential for cross-checking dosage form and route. Because this information is pre-coordinated into 'code' for SNOMED, it is marked as optional.
