Cascading of trigger event objects allows different messages to employ consistent and common objects.
Attribute is mandatory to ensure that cascading will be specified one way or another.
Information pertaining to a patient's agreement/acceptance to have his/her clinical information electronically stored and shared.

This will usually only be populated for queries, but could be used for updates if a jurisdiction requires consent before recording information in the EHR (e.g. consent to participate in electronic data exchange).
Note: keywords canot be passed from one application to another via the EHR (e.g. prescriber to dispenser via a Drug Information System).
Provides authorization to record and/or view patient information.

Indicates the consent or keyword used to authorize access or update, including a reason for access; May also be used to override access restriction to the information ('break the glass') on a message by message basis.
May be required on a Prescription Request to indicate a keyword for drug utilization processing.
Indicates that the consent was provided by the patient or representative.
Consent can be provided by the patient or representative or be overridden by a provider. It is important to know which occurred for audit purposes.
Indicates whether the patient's consent is written or verbal.
Verbal consents may trigger a higher level of auditing.
Indicates that information access was approved by a provider rather than a patient. I.e. This is an override rather than an actual consent.
Clinical circumstances may demand that a patient's information be accessed without consent to ensure patient safety.
Indicates the type of information access consented to
Provides details about the consent
Information pertaining to a patient's agreement/acceptance to have his/her clinical information electronically stored and shared.
Provides authorization to record and/or view patient information.
If code is INFA, then InformDefinition must be present, otherwise it must be absent
One and only one of author1 (Consenter) and author2 (Provider) must be specified
If author2 (provider) is specified, reasonCode must be specified
A unique identifier for a specific consent for a patient.
Provides a traceable audit link between a physical consent form and its electronic record
Indicates the type of consent being given: Information access or Information maintenance.
Distinguishes what type of consent is being dealt with and is therefore mandatory.
If true, indicates that consent has explicitly *not* been given.
Primarily applies for global "participation" consent, when there is a need to track whether the patient has consented, not consented, or has not recorded a decision.
Because not all jurisdictions will track "participation" consent, this attribute is optional. In jurisdictions where it is supported, the element must always be valued as either true or false.
Must be either not present or non-null.
Indicates the time that the consent will expire. 'Low' is effective time and 'High' is end time.
Most consents are not open-ended, to ensure the patient retains a level of control
Indicates a reason for overriding a patient's consent rules or accessing information without consent.
Important for audit purposes
Indicates that consent was granted by the patient themselves
Allows assertion of who issued the consent.
Describes the type of information access being consented to.
Allows fine-grained control over the types of information access is granted to and who is granted access.
Identifies the beneficiary of the consent as being a Provider or Service Location.
Indicates who is being authorized to receive the information, and is therefore populated.
The type of patient information that can be accessed or modified.

Different consents may need access to different types of patient information (e.g. demographics, medications, allergies, lab results). Understanding the type of information the consent applies to is critical to controlling access, and therefore the attribute is mandatory.
Indicates that revision to the keyword was requested by the patient or representative.
Indicates who is responsible for changing the keyword, and is therefore mandatory
Indicate the keyword associated with a particular consent.
Allows patients to change their keyword. If explicitly set to null, removes the keyword for the identified record types. Because of this, the attribute is set to 'populated'.
Information pertaining to a patient's secret password used to control access to his/her health information.
Allows a patient to control access to their health information. Provides authorization for providers to view patient information.
Indicates that the keyword was changed by the patient themselves.
Sometimes keywords are changed by the patient, sometimes by a patient representative.
The type of patient information that can be accessed or modified. Examples are: demographics, medications, lab, DI, etc
The keyword revisioning process may also involve revising the list of information types covered by the keyword.

Different keywords may be needed to access different types of patient information (e.g. demographics, medications, allergies, lab results). Understanding the type of information the keyword applies to is critical, and therefore the attribute is mandatory.
Indicates the categories of information governed whose access is governed by the keyword.
Allows the patient to selectively apply diffent keywords to different information categories.
At least one information category must be identified, thus this participation is mandatory.
A specific material or agent that to which the patient was exposed. Examples are: Codein (Drug), Peanut (Food), etc.
Allows the provider to zero in on specific culprits for the adverse reaction.
Indicates the specific allergy test that supports the recording of the allergy/intolerance.
Provides evidence for recording the allergy/intolerance.
Value is required if not using SNOMED
At least one of Id or Value must be specified.
An identifier for a specific instance of an allergy/intolerance test.
Allows an allergy/intolerance test record to be directly referenced.
A coded value denoting the type of allergy test conducted.
Allows different kinds of allergy/intolerance tests to be distinguishable and is therefore mandatory. It uses the CD type to support SNOMED post-coordination.
The date on which the allergy test was performed.
Allows providers to evaluate the currency of the test.
A code indicating result of the allergy test.

Allows other providers to evaluate the test. There is no point in associating an allergy test with unknown results with an allergy or intolerance however the element is optional because this information may be post-coordinated in the 'code' attribute using SNOMED.
This is a recording of a patient reaction that is believed to be associated with the allergy/intolerance.

Helps providers to distinguish between proper allergies and intolerances. Allows the provider recording the allergy to assign appropriate severity to the allergy. May give insight on how to mitigate an intolerance that is likely to be triggered by administering a substance. (E.g. If a given drug typically causes nausea in the patient, an additional medication may be co-prescribed to manage the nausea.)
Value is required if not using SNOMED
Reaction Assessment code must be fixed to RXNASSESS if not using SNOMED
Indicates the type of assessment being made
For SNOMED this will include the actual assessment. For non-SNOMED, this should be fixed to RXNASSES.

Communicates the relatedness assessment of the exposure to the reaction and is therefore mandatory. For SNOMED this will communicate the full assessment. It is expressed as a CD to allow for SNOMED post-coordination.
Indicates whether the reaction is deemed to be related to the exposure.
This attribute will not be populated if using SNOMED. Otherwise it should have a fixed value of "RELATED".
Creates the link between the exposure and the reaction. Because the details of the assessment will be communicated in the 'code' attribute for SNOMED, this element is optional.
Indicates the specific substance involved in the incidence that caused the reaction.
Identification of offending substance is needed for management of the reaction.
Incidence of the patient's exposure to (or contact with) with some material that might have caused the adverse reaction.
Examples of exposures include: Administering a substance (drug, food, etc) to the patient, Patient coming into contact with an environmental material, etc.
Communicates the cause of the adverse reaction.
Identifier of the record or order that caused the reaction. This could be an identifier for a prescription, immunization, or other active medication record.
Allows for drilling down to retrieve further information about the exposure
The method by which the patient was exposed to the substance.
Helps evaluate the cause of the reaction.

Indicates where the information that led to the recording of this information came from. The possible 3 sources of the information are: the patient, the patient's representative or a health-care provider.
The original source of the information can be important in evaluating its accuracy and importance.
The date on which the allergy/intolerance was reported.
Allows for establishment of timelines between onset date, reported date and recorded date, and is therefore mandatory.
A record of a patient's allergy or intolerance.
Necessary component of a person's overall medication and clinical profile. Helps with drug contraindication checking.
Value is mandatory if not using SNOMED
A coded value denoting whether the record pertains to an intolerance or a true allergy. (Allergies result from immunologic reactions. Intolerances do not.)

Allows for the separation of allergy and intolerance records. The type of condition is critical to understanding the record and is therefore mandatory. It is expressed as a CD to allow for SNOMED post-coordination.
An indication that the allergy/intolerance has been refuted. I.e. A clinician has positively determined that the patient does not suffer from a particular allergy or intolerance.
Allows providers to refute a previously confirmed or suspected allergy. The attribute is mandatory because it is essential to know whether a record is refuted or not.
A coded value that indicates whether an allergy/intolerance is 'active' or 'completed' (indicating no longer active).
System must default the status to 'active'.
Allows providers to evaluate the relevance of a recorded allergy/intolerance. The status has a default value of 'active' and is therefore mandatory.
The date on which the recorded allergy is considered active.
Allows providers to evaluate the period of relevance for the allergy/intolerance record.

Denotes access restriction placed on the allergy or intolerance record. Methods for accessing masked allergy records will be governed by each jurisdiction (e.g. court orders, shared secret/consent, etc.).
Provides support for additional confidentiality constraint, giving patients a level of control over their information.
Valid values are: 'N' (normal - denotes 'Not Masked'); 'R' (restricted - denotes 'Masked') and 'T' (taboo - denotes 'Patient Access Restricted').
The default is 'normal' signifying 'Not Masked'.
Provides support for additional confidentiality constraint to reflect the wishes of the patient.
Taboo allows the provider to request restricted access to patient or their care giver.
Constraint: Can’t have both normal and one of the other codes simultaneously.
The attribute is optional because not all systems will support masking.
An indication of the level of confidence/surety placed in the recorded information.
The two valid codes are:

- U (stated with uncertainty) -Specifies that the author of the act affirms the uncertainty of the act statement. In other words, they know that parts of the act statement are not certain or are inferred. An example of this is an inferred prescription where some order data is inferred from a supply event (i.e. dispense).

- N (stated with no assertion of uncertainty) - Specifies that the act statement is made without any explicit expression of certainty/uncertainty. This is the normal statement, meaning that it may not be free of errors and uncertainty may still exist. In healthcare, N is believed to express certainty to the strength possible.
An allergy or intolerance record is always used in drug contraindication checking whether the record is U or N.
Helps other providers to make appropriate decisions in their management of allergy or intolerance contraindications.
Attribute is mandatory because an allergy or intolerance record must be tagged as either U or N.
Indicates the substance to which the patient is allergic
Critical for identifying the allergy or intolerance. However, because the attribute is not used for SNOMED, it is optional.
Category of material or agent to which the patient was exposed.
Allows exposed materials or agents to be collectively referenced.
Indicates the type of agent that the patient was exposed to which caused the adverse reaction. This includes Drug, Food, Latex, Dust, etc.

Allows different kinds of reaction agents to be distinguished. Coding strength is set to CWE because the exposure agent type may not always be codified. The attribute is populated because there is little point in communicating about the exposure to an agent if it is not known what the agent is, however it may not always be coded. Also, the code may sometimes be masked, in which case a "null flavor" must be specified.
Value is required if not using SNOMED
Reaction Code must be fixed to DX if not using SNOMED
At least one of Id or Value must be specified.
An identifier assigned to the record of the adverse reaction.
Allows for direct referencing of an adverse reaction record which was previously recorded.
Indicates the type of diagnosis being captured.
If using SNOMED, this will contain the diagnosis. Otherwise it will be a fixed value of 'DX'.
Indicates that the observation is actually a diagnosis and is therefore mandatory. The datatype is CD to support SNOMED post-coordination.
Indicates if there was an there was no adverse reaction when the patient was exposed to the agent to which an allergy/intolerance has been recorded.

Allows providers to confirm or eliminate specific agents as being the cause for the allergy/intolerance. E.g. If a reaction is recorded for Tylenol 3, but no reaction is recorded for regular Tylenol or for coffee, this suggests that the likely cause of the allergy is Codeine.
The element is mandatory because it is essential to know for a given record whether the reaction occurred or not.
A free form description of the reaction.
Allows for flexibility in the recording and reporting of the reaction.
The date on which the reaction occurrence began.
Indicates when evidence of the condition first appeared. May also provide information on the duration of the reaction.
Specifies the kind of reaction, as experienced by the patient.

Ensures consistency in tracking and categorizing the reaction type. Helps ensure that only proper allergies are categorized as allergy. The attribute is optional because it will not be used for SNOMED. The attribute is CWE because not all possible types of reactions are expressible by coded values.
This is a ranking/ an assertion of the seriouness of the diagnosed/reported medical condition.
Allows providers to determine appropriate managements for contraindications involving such medical conditions.
Indicates the gravity of the allergy, intolerance or reaction in terms of its actual or potential impact on the patient.
Allows for sorting of allergy records. May influence whether contraindications must be managed. Because SNOMED pre-coordinates severity into 'code', the attribute is optional.
AllergyIntolerance.severity
Indicates the agent that is believed to have caused the adverse reaction.
Provides support for the agent identified as the allergen/intolerance source.
An indication of the severity of the reaction.
Allows providers to evaluate the significance of the allergy or intolerance. Because reaction severity is communicated as part of the code for SNOMED, this associaiton is optional.
SeverityObservation must not be present if using SNOMED for ReactionObservationEvent.code
Indicates the severity of the allergy/intolerance.
Useful for determining severity of an allergy/intolerance contraindication and the management of same. The association is optional because severity will be precoordinated into code for SNOMED.
SeverityObservation must not be present if ConditionEvent.code is using SNOMED
Indicates the various comments that providers have recorded about this allergy/intolerance.
Improves communication between providers by allowing a mechanism to exchange un-coded free-form information.
Indicates a particular type of reaction experienced by the patient or testing performed on the patient which provides evidence for the existence (or non-existence) of the allergy/intolerance.
May help ascertain the severity of the condition, and provide direction for management. Also helps demonstrate the distinction between allergies and intolerances
A specific material or agent that to which the patient was exposed. Examples are: Codein (Drug), Peanut (Food), etc.
Allows the provider to zero in on specific culprits for the adverse reaction.
This is a recording of the exposures and causality assessment deemed to be related to the reaction.
Indicates both the product and how related they are determined to be to the reaction.
value is mandatory if not using SNOMED
Code is fixed to RXNASSESS if not using SNOMED
Indicates the type of assessment being made
For SNOMED this will include the actual assessment. For non-SNOMED, this should be fixed to RXNASSES.

Communicates the relatedness assessment of the exposure to the reaction and is therefore mandatory. For SNOMED this will communicate the full assessment. It is expressed as a CD to allow for SNOMED post-coordination.
Indicates whether the reaction is deemed to be related to the exposure.
This attribute will not be populated if using SNOMED. Otherwise it should have a fixed value of "RELATED".
Creates the link between the exposure and the reaction. Because the details of the assessment will be communicated in the 'code' attribute for SNOMED, this element is optional.
Indicates the specific substance involved in the incidence that caused the reaction.
Identification of offending substance is needed for management of the reaction.
Incidence of the patient's exposure to (or contact with) with some material that might have caused the adverse reaction.
Examples of exposures include: Administering a substance (drug, food, etc) to the patient, Patient coming into contact with an environmental material, etc.
Communicates the cause of the adverse reaction.
routeCode is required if not using SNOMED
Identifier of the exposure event that caused the adverse reaction. This could be an identifier for a prescription, immunization, or other active medication record.
Allows for drilling down to retrieve further information about the exposure
The method by which the patient was exposed to the substance.
Helps evaluate the cause of the reaction.

Indicates where the information that led to the recording of this information came from. The possible 3 sources of the information are: the patient, the patient's representative or a health-care provider.
The original source of the information can be important in evaluating its accuracy and importance.
The date on which the adverse reaction was reported.
Allows for establishment of timelines between onset date, reported date and recorded date, and is therefore mandatory.
Category of material or agent to which the patient was exposed.
Allows exposed materials or agents to be collectively referenced.
Indicates the type of agent that the patient was exposed to which caused the adverse reaction. This includes Drug, Food, Latex, Dust, etc.

Allows different kinds of reaction agents to be distinguished. Coding strength is set to CWE because the exposure agent type may not always be codified. The attribute is populated because there is little point in communicating about the exposure to an agent if it is not known what the agent is, however it may not always be coded. Also, the code may sometimes be masked, in which case a "null flavor" must be specified.
Indicates the name of the agent identified by MaterialKind.code
Provides a human-readable name in circumstances where the agent is captured as a code.
This is a record of an adverse reaction considered relevant to the patient's clincal record.

Useful in tracking reactions when it is not known precisely what product they are associated with and whether the reaction is due to an allergy or intolerance, a drug interaction or some other cause. Effectively gives a 'heads up' to clinicians using the drug or combination of drugs.
Value is mandatory if not using SNOMED
Code is fixed to DX if not using SNOMED
Indicates the type of diagnosis being captured.
If using SNOMED, this will contain the diagnosis. Otherwise it will be a fixed value of 'DX'.
Indicates that the observation is actually a diagnosis and is therefore mandatory. The datatype is CD to support SNOMED post-coordination.
A free form description of the reaction.
This is a specific description of the reaction, as opposed to annotations on the reaction.

Annotations and text are quite different. Think of it from a user interface. Notes might be things like "patient didn't have the problem when the took the medication two weeks earlier" or "patient thinks it might have been related to the two bottles of scotch they drank the night prior", which aren't describing the reaction but are relevant to the reaction record
Allows for flexibility in the recording and reporting of the reaction.
The date on which the reaction occurrence began.
Indicates when evidence of the condition first appeared. May also provide information on the duration of the reaction.
Communicates the intent of the patient to restrict access to their adverse reactions.
Provides support for additional confidentiality constraint, giving patients a level of control over their information.
Allows a provider to request restricted access by the patient.
Valid values are: 'N' (normal - denotes 'Not Masked'); 'R' (restricted - denotes 'Masked') and 'T' (taboo - denotes 'Patient Access Restricted').
The default is 'normal' signifying 'Not Masked'.
Allows the patient to have discrete control over access to their adverse reaction data.
Taboo allows the provider to request restricted access to patient or their care giver.
Constraint: Can’t have both normal and one of the other codes simultaneously.
The attribute is optional because not all systems will support masking.
Specifies the kind of reaction, as experienced by the patient.

Ensures consistency in tracking and categorizing the reaction type. Helps ensure that only proper allergies are categorized as allergy. The attribute is optional because it will not be used for SNOMED. The attribute is CWE because not all possible types of reactions are expressible by coded values.
This is a ranking/ an assertion of the seriouness of the diagnosed/reported medical condition.
Allows providers to determine appropriate managements for contraindications involving such medical conditions.
Indicates the gravity of the allergy, intolerance or reaction in terms of its actual or potential impact on the patient.
Allows for sorting of reactions. May influence whether contraindications must be managed. Because SNOMED pre-coordinates this concept into code, the association is optional
AllergyIntolerance.severity
Indicates the severity of the allergy/intolerance.

Useful for determining severity of an allergy/intolerance contraindication and the management of same. Because reaction severity is communicated as part of the code for SNOMED, this associaiton is optional.
SeverityObservation must not be present if ReactionObservationEvent.code is using SNOMED
Indicates the various comments that providers have recorded about this adverse reaction.
Improves communication between providers by allowing a mechanism to exchange un-coded free-form information.
Indicates the agent(s) that are suspected to have been involved in the adverse reaction.
Allows linking the reaction to one or more drugs so that they can be flagged in the future when prescribed or dispensed.
Indicates that the result set should be filtered to include only those allergy/intolerance records for the specified status. Valid statuses include: ACTIVE or COMPLETE.
Allows for the selective retrieval of allergy/intolerance records based on the status of the record.
A coded value indicating whether to return an allergy record or an intolerance record. The result set will be filtered to include only allergy records or intolerance records accordingly.
Allows allergy/intolerance records to be selectively searched and retrieved.
Filters the query response to only include allergy/intolerance records which have been created or modified within the date-range specified.
Useful in retrieving incremental changes to the patient's record.
Filters the records retrieved to only include those associated with the specified encounter, episode or care event. If unspecified, no filter is applied.

Note: When matching on care composition id, systems should also retrieve records with a fulfillment id to requisitions associated with the care composition. E.g. When retrieving records associated with an encounter which includes a referral, the retrieved records should also include the care summary created in fulfillment of the referral.
Allows retrieving all records associated with an encounter, episode or care event.
Filters the records retrieved to only include those associated with the specified 'kind' of encounter, episode or care event. If unspecified, no filter is applied.
Allows retrieving all records associated with a particular type of encounter, episode or care event. E.g.Orthopedic Clinic Encounter, ER encounter, Walk-in encounter, etc.
Indicates whether or not notes attached to the allergy/intolerance records are to be returned along with the detailed information.
Allows for the flexibility of omitting/including notes in the retrieval of information for allergy/intolerance data.
Because the attribute is boolean, it must explicitly indicate a 'TRUE' or 'FALSE', and thus it is mandatory.
Defines the set of parameters that may be used to filter the query response
Root class for query definition
A coded value denoting a specific reaction. E.g. Code for 'rash'. The result set will be filtered to include only those allergy records or intolerance records pertaining to the specified reaction.
Allows allergy/intolerance records to be selectively searched and retrieved.
A specific material or agent that to which the patient was exposed. Examples are: Codein (Drug), Peanut (Food), etc.
Allows the provider to zero in on specific culprits for the adverse reaction.
Indicates the specific allergy test that supports the recording of the allergy/intolerance.
Provides evidence for recording the allergy/intolerance.
Value is mandatory if not using SNOMED
An identifier for a specific instance of an allergy/intolerance test.
Allows an allergy/intolerance test record to be directly referenced.
A coded value denoting the type of allergy test conducted.
Allows different kinds of allergy/intolerance tests to be distinguishable and is therefore mandatory. It uses the CD type to support SNOMED post-coordination.
The date on which the allergy test was performed.
Allows providers to evaluate the currency of the test.
A code indicating result of the allergy test.

Allows other providers to evaluate the test. There is no point in associating an allergy test with unknown results with an allergy or intolerance however the element is optional because this information may be post-coordinated in the 'code' attribute using SNOMED.
If present, indicates that there are notes associated with the allergy or intolerance.
Shows whether additional information is available on further drill-down
Identifies the provider who reported the allergy or intolerance.
Identifies responsibility for accuracy and relevance of the information. This association reflects primary responsibility, and is therefore mandatory.
The date and time on which the allergy/intolerance record was created.
Identifies timing of allergy/intolerance for sorting and for audit purposes. Attribute is populated because the source of the data may not be through the 'record allergy/intolerance' interaction.
This is a recording of a patient reaction that is believed to be associated with the allergy/intolerance.

Helps providers to distinguish between proper allergies and intolerances. Allows the provider recording the allergy to assign appropriate severity to the allergy. May give insight on how to mitigate an intolerance that is likely to be triggered by administering a substance. (E.g. If a given drug typically causes nausea in the patient, an additional medication may be co-prescribed to manage the nausea.)
Value is mandatory if not using SNOMED
Code must be fixed to RXNASSESS if not using SNOMED
Indicates the type of assessment being made
For SNOMED this will include the actual assessment. For non-SNOMED, this should be fixed to RXNASSESS.

Communicates the relatedness assessment of the exposure to the reaction and is therefore mandatory. For SNOMED this will communicate the full assessment. It is expressed as a CD to allow for SNOMED post-coordination.
Indicates whether the reaction is deemed to be related to the exposure.
This attribute will not be populated if using SNOMED. Otherwise it should have a fixed value of "RELATED".
Creates the link between the exposure and the reaction. Because the details of the assessment will be communicated in the 'code' attribute for SNOMED, this element is optional.
Associates the event with other care events
Allows for grouping the current event with other care events.
Indicates the specific substance involved in the incidence that caused the reaction.
Identification of offending substance is needed for management of the reaction.
Incidence of the patient's exposure to (or contact with) with some material that might have caused the adverse reaction.
Examples of exposures include: Administering a substance (drug, food, etc) to the patient, Patient coming into contact with an environmental material, etc.
Communicates the cause of the adverse reaction.
Identifier of the exposure event that caused the adverse reaction. This could be an identifier for a prescription, immunization, or other active medication record.
Allows for drilling down to retrieve further information about the exposure
The method by which the patient was exposed to the substance.
Helps evaluate the cause of the reaction.

Indicates where the information that led to the recording of this information came from. The possible 3 sources of the information are: the patient, the patient's representative or a health-care provider.
The original source of the information can be important in evaluating its accuracy and importance.
The date on which the allergy/intolerance was reported.
Allows for establishment of timelines between onset date, reported date and recorded date, and is therefore mandatory.
A record of a patient's allergy or intolerance.
Necessary component of a person's overall medication and clinical profile. Helps with drug contraindication checking.
Value is mandatory if not using SNOMED
Unique identifier for an allergy/intolerance record.
Allows for direct referencing of an allergy/intolerance record when querying or performing updates and is therefore mandatory.
A coded value denoting whether the record pertains to an intolerance or a true allergy. (Allergies result from immunologic reactions. Intolerances do not.)

Allows for the separation of allergy and intolerance records. The type of condition is critical to understanding the record and is therefore mandatory. It is expressed as a CD to allow for SNOMED post-coordination.
An indication that the allergy/intolerance has been refuted. I.e. A clinician has positively determined that the patient does not suffer from a particular allergy or intolerance.

Allows providers to refute a previously confirmed or suspected allergy. The attribute is mandatory because it is critical to know whether the record represents the refutation or affirmation of an allergy or intolerance.
A coded value that indicates whether an allergy/intolerance is 'ACTIVE' or 'COMPLETE' (indicating no longer active).
System must default the status to 'ACTIVE'.
Allows providers to evaluate the relevance of a recorded allergy/intolerance. The status has a default value of 'ACTIVE' and is therefore mandatory.
The date on which the recorded allergy is considered active.
Allows providers to evaluate the period of relevance for the allergy/intolerance record.

Denotes access restriction placed on the allergy or intolerance record. Methods for accessing masked allergy records will be governed by each jurisdiction (e.g. court orders, shared secret/consent, etc.).
Provides support for additional confidentiality constraint, giving patients a level of control over their information.
Allows a provider to request restricted access by the patient.
Valid values are: 'N' (normal - denotes 'Not Masked'); 'R' (restricted - denotes 'Masked') and 'T' (taboo - denotes 'Patient Access Restricted').
The default is 'normal' signifying 'Not Masked'.
Provides support for additional confidentiality constraint to reflect the wishes of the patient.
Taboo allows the provider to request restricted access to patient or their care giver.
Constraint: Can’t have both normal and one of the other codes simultaneously.
The attribute is required because even if a jurisdiction doesn't support masking on the way in, it will need to need to communicate masked data returned from other jurisdictions.
An indication of the level of confidence/surety placed in the recorded information.
The two valid codes are:

- U (stated with uncertainty) -Specifies that the author of the act affirms the uncertainty of the act statement. In other words, they know that parts of the act statement are not certain or are inferred. An example of this is an inferred prescription where some order data is inferred from a supply event (i.e. dispense).

- N (stated with no assertion of uncertainty) - Specifies that the act statement is made without any explicit expression of certainty/uncertainty. This is the normal statement, meaning that it may not be free of errors and uncertainty may still exist. In healthcare, N is believed to express certainty to the strength possible.
An allergy or intolerance record is always used in drug contraindication checking whether the record is U or N
Helps other providers to make appropriate decisions in their management of allergy or intolerance contraindications.
Attribute is mandatory because an allergy or intolerance record must be tagged as either U or N.
Indicates the substance to which the patient is allergic
Critical for identifying the allergy or intolerance. Because it is not used for SNOMED, this element is optional.
Indicates the service delivery location where the allergy was recorded.

Indicates where records are likely kept for follow-up. May also be useful in understanding the context in which the allergy/intolerance was recorded. The location of entry should always be known, and is therefore mandatory.
Category of material or agent to which the patient was exposed.
Allows exposed materials or agents to be collectively referenced.
Indicates the type of agent that the patient was exposed to which caused the adverse reaction. This includes Drug, Food, Latex, Dust, etc.

Allows different kinds of reaction agents to be distinguished. Coding strength is set to CWE because the exposure agent type may not always be codified. The attribute is populated because there is little point in communicating about the exposure to an agent if it is not known what the agent is, however it may not always be coded.
This is a recording of a patient reaction that is believed to be associated with the allergy/intolerance.

Helps providers to distinguish between proper allergies and intolerances. Allows the provider recording the allergy to assign appropriate severity to the allergy. May give insight on how to mitigate an intolerance that is likely to be triggered by administering a substance. (E.g. If a given drug typically causes nausea in the patient, an additional medication may be co-prescribed to manage the nausea.)
Value must be mandatory if not using SNOMED
Code must be fixed to DX if not using SNOMED
An identifier assigned to the record of the adverse reaction.
Allows for direct referencing of an adverse reaction record which was previously recorded.
Indicates the type of diagnosis being captured.
If using SNOMED, this will contain the diagnosis. Otherwise it will be a fixed value of 'DX'.
Indicates that the observation is actually a diagnosis and is therefore mandatory. The datatype is CD to support SNOMED post-coordination.
Indicates if there there was an adverse reaction when the patient was exposed to the agent to which an allergy/intolerance has been recorded.

Allows providers to confirm or eliminate specific agents as being the cause for the allergy/intolerance. E.g. If a reaction is recorded for Tylenol 3, but no reaction is recorded for regular Tylenol or for coffee, this suggests that the likely cause of the allergy is Codeine.
The attribute is mandatory because it is essential to know whether the reaction occurred or not.
A free form description of the reaction.
Allows for flexibility in the recording and reporting of the reaction.
The date on which the reaction occurrence began.
Indicates when evidence of the condition first appeared. May also provide information on the duration of the reaction.
Specifies the kind of reaction, as experienced by the patient.

Ensures consistency in tracking and categorizing the reaction type. Helps ensure that only proper allergies are categorized as allergy. The attribute is optional because it will not be used for SNOMED. The attribute is CWE because not all possible types of reactions are expressible by coded values.
Identity of the provider who is taking responsibility for the actions of the author.
Allows for the trail of responsibility for the action.
This is a ranking/ an assertion of the seriouness of the diagnosed/reported medical condition.
Allows providers to determine appropriate managements for contraindications involving such medical conditions.
Indicates the gravity of the allergy, intolerance or reaction in terms of its actual or potential impact on the patient.
Allows for sorting of allergy records. May influence whether contraindications must be managed. Because this concept is pre-coordinated with code for SNOMED, the association is optional.
Indicates the agent that is believed to have caused the adverse reaction.
Provides support for the agent identified as the allergen/intolerance source.
An indication of the severity of the reaction.
Allows providers to evaluate the significance of the allergy or intolerance. Because severity is communicated as part of the reaction code in SNOMED, this association is optional
Severity Observation must not be present if using SNOMED
Indicates the severity of the allergy/intolerance.

Useful for determining severity of an allergy/intolerance contraindication and the management of same. Because allergy severity is communicated as part of the code for SNOMED, this associaiton is optional.
Not sent if Condition code is SNOMED
Indicates the various comments that providers have recorded about this allergy/intolerance.
Improves communication between providers by allowing a mechanism to exchange un-coded free-form information.
This association is mandatory as it indicates one of presence or absence notes.
Indicates the various comments that providers have recorded about this allergy or intolerance record.
Improves communication between providers by allowing a mechanism to exchange un-coded free-form information.
Indicates a particular type of reaction experienced by the patient or testing performed on the patient which provides evidence for the existence (or non-existence) of the allergy/intolerance.
May help ascertain the severity of the condition, and provide direction for management. Also helps demonstrate the distinction between allergies and intolerances
A specific material or agent that to which the patient was exposed. Examples are: Codein (Drug), Peanut (Food), etc.
Allows the provider to zero in on specific culprits for the adverse reaction.
Identifies the provider who reported the reaction.
Identifies responsibility for accuracy and relevance of the information. This association reflects primary responsibility, and is therefore mandatory.
The date and time on which the adverse reaction record was created.
Identifies timing of adverse reaction for sorting and for audit purposes. Attribute is populated because the source of the data may not be through the 'record common observation' interaction.
This is a recording of the exposures and causality assessment deemed to be related to the reaction.
Indicates both the product and how related they are determined to be to the reaction.
Value is mandatory if not using SNOMED
Code is fixed to RXNASSESS if not using SNOMED

Indicates the name of the agent identified by MaterialKind.code
Provides a human-readable name in circumstances where the agent is captured as code.
This is a record of an adverse reaction considered relevant to the patient's clinical record.

Useful in tracking reactions when it is not known precisely what product they are associated with and whether the reaction is due to an allergy or intolerance, a drug interaction or some other cause. Effectively gives a 'heads up' to clinicians using the drug or combination of drugs.
Value is mandatory if not using SNOMED
Code is fixed to DX if not using SNOMED

Identity of the health service provider responsible for the change in the allergy/intolerance status.

In an EHR integrated health services environment, it is important that other providers are able to query who is responsible for a given change. Also used by applications for auditing and sorting. The attribute is mandatory because the responsible provider should always be known.
The date on which the change was made.

Gives other providers the frame of reference in evaluating any post-change issues with the allergy. Also used for sorting and audit purposes. Time of change is always known and thus the attribute is mandatory.

This records the history of changes that have been made to the allergy/intolerance, including why the changes were made, who made them and when.
Provides a record of a patient's allergy changes, providing deeper clinical understanding, particularly of past clinical decisions.
Identifies what kind of change occurred. Allergy/Intolerance change types are Revise, Reactivate and Complete.
This attribute is mandatory to ensure that change types are distinguishable.
The date on which the various changes of an allergy/intolerance become valid and applicable.
Allows applications to sort and filter by time. The date on which a change is effective should always be known and thus is mandatory.
Denotes the reason the the allergy/intolerance was changed.
Ensures consistent terminology in capturing and interpreting reasons for change. Allows CWE because not all reasons will correspond to a pre-defined code.
